clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Oxytocin on Face Perception
clinical_study.official_title: The Behavioral and Neural Effects of Oxytocin on Face Perception in Congenital Prosopagnosia

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether oxytocin affect face perception

clinical_study.why_stopped: We are currently engaged in other behavioral study.

primary_outcome.description: At the day participants will administer the substance, they will view a set of faces, of which they will be tested about 24 hours later. The measures that will be tested are %accuracy and %dwell time of eye movements towards each region in the faces the participants saw.

secondary_outcome.description: Participants will fill a PANAS mood questionnaire in order to monitor the effects of mood and fatigue of oxytocin/placebo. We will use ANOVA on the total score of the test in order to verify that differences in performance are not due to change in mood or fatigue after substance uptake.

arm_group.description: Control group will be administered oxytocin and placebo, in a double-blind randomized order.
Congenital prosopagnosics will be administered oxytocin and placebo in a double-blind randomized order.

intervention.description: Intervention will be examined on control group, and on experimental group as well.
Placebo will be given to control group and experimental group as well.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- normal or corrected to normal vision
Exclusion Criteria:
- minors
- pregnancy (according to a pregnancy test taken by subjects prior to participation)
- a history of asthma or nasal polyps
- cardiac disorders
- hyponatremia
- acute or chronic renal insufficiency
- liver cirrhosis
- neurological disease
- other chronic disease
- dementia, or lack of judgment
